title: Can corporations ever become powerful enough to have their own armies? - Quora

response.answer_text: Sure. Many already are. However, it is not cost efficient to raise an army. It is much less expensive to bribe some key politicians to let them borrow the army of a powerful nation. Just ask any oil company or the Federal Reserve in the United States. They have been doing it for decades. In days past, railroads used the US Army to get rid of Indians who objected to train tracks being built across their hunting grounds and scaring away all the game. Go back even further than that and the large mercantile corporations used the militaries of Britain, Portugal, Spain and other European countries to protect their properties and trade routes. Sometimes it was difficult to determine where the private security force of a mercantile company ended and the military of a colonial power began.

Yes, what generally prevents this is laws against such things but even today there are corporations that could maintain a small army or hire private contractors to fulfill that role. There are already corporations that are private armies, mainly limited by what equipment they can obtain.

In the 1700 and 1800 the British East India Company supported a massive private army in India. They were co-equal with the British army at the time and often collaborated with the British army in military operations. Today private corporations hire mercenaries via military type ‘security companies’ to protect their overseas operations. In Viet Nam Air America worked for the not only the CIA, but for various private firms with business interest in that country.
